Discover the wonderful world of Sea Turtles!

Seven different species of sea (or marine) turtles grace our ocean waters, from the shallow seagrass beds of the Indian Ocean, to the colorful reefs of the Coral Triangle
and the sandy beaches of the Eastern Pacific. Read on to find out more!


Top 10 facts about Sea Turtles:


  1. Around 100 million years ago Sea turtles lived alongside dinosaurs.

  2. There are seven species of marine turtle. Six of these are classed as endangered species.

    • Hawksbill


    • Leatherback


    • Green Turtle


    • Olive Ridley


    • Flatback


    • Loggerhead


    • Kemp's Ridley



  3. Sea Turtles don't have teeth but use their beak shaped mouth which is made of keratin to catch food.

  4. They cannot retract into their shell unlike other turtles.

  5. They do not breathe under water but can hold their breath for 5 hours under water.

  6. Wales holds the world record for the largest marine turtle ever found. It measured over 2.5 metres long and weighed more than 140 stone!

  7. Marine turtles have an amazing ability to navigate. This comes from their sensitivity to the Earth's magnetic fields.

  8. They often travel large distances to migrate, travelling over 20 miles per day.
    The longest known record is for a female leatherback who swam nearly 13,000 miles over 647 days from Indonesia to the west coast of America.

  9. Sea turtles are a fundamental link in marine ecosystems. They eat Jellyfish which helps to manage the dangerous Jellyfish population. They also help to maintain the health of seagrass beds and coral reefs that benefit commercially valuable species such as shrimp, lobster, and tuna. This why they need to be protected.

  10. Sea turtles live a long time (some can live up to 50 years or more) so they have a similar lifespans to humans.
